questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with altered mental status, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 57-year-old man is brought to the physician for worsening mental status over the past 2 months. His wife reports that he was initially experiencing lapses in memory, and over the past 3 weeks, he has started having difficulty performing activities of daily living. Yesterday, he got lost going to the post office down the street. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert but verbally uncommunicative. Muscle strength is normal. Reflexes are 2+ in bilateral upper and lower extremities. He has diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. Mental status examination shows a blunt affect. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Alzheimer disease initially manifests with short-term memory loss and temporospatial disorientation, as seen in this patient, impaired naming and language comprehension, as well as mood and behavioral changes would also be prominent. Myoclonus does not occur in the early stages of Alzheimer disease. Most importantly, Alzheimer disease has an insidious onset and progresses slowly over several years, whereas this patient's symptoms progressed rapidly within 2 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease may manifest with signs of dementia, but the hallmark findings of Parkinson disease are bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) manifests with movement abnormalities and the defining symptom is chorea, which is absent in this patient. Furthermore, myoclonus is an atypical symptom of HD that occurs only rarely. Neuropsychiatric symptoms such as dementia and apathy can occur but appear at advanced stages, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressing mental decline combined with myoclonus and mutism, as seen in this patient, are typical clinical findings in patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The disease has a rapid course that often leads to death within 12 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Although amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically manifests in patients between 50 and 60 years and may cause cognitive impairment in some patients, memory loss is not a typical early finding in this disease. Additionally, ALS manifests with asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) may manifest in some patients with memory deficits but this usually occurs as a very late feature. Additionally, MS typically manifests with impaired vision, color blindness, Lhermitte sign, absence of abdominal reflex, and signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign), none of which are present in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease may present with cognitive impairment and myoclonus, but neurologic features, such as dysarthria, parkinsonism, and drooling, are much more common. Other typical findings of Wilson disease, such as liver damage and Kayser-Fleischer rings, are also absent. Finally, the disease typically manifests in patients < 35 years of age.

H) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus may manifest with signs of dementia, but clinical features also include gait disturbances and urinary incontinence, which this patient lacks. Additionally, normal pressure hydrocephalus usually presents in older patients (> 60 years of age) or as a consequence of CNS infections and intracranial hemorrhages.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

I) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior (e.g., inappropriate social behavior) while memory and orientation initially remain intact, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
questions.hint: The electroencephalogram of this patient with rapidly progressing symptoms of dementia would show triphasic periodic sharp-wave complexes.

questions.text:
For each patient with altered mental status, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 55-year-old man is brought to the physician because of inappropriate behavior for the past 6 months. He has been making inappropriate comments and jokes while talking to friends and family members. He was arrested 3 weeks ago while trying to kiss strangers on the street. He also has lost interest in talking to his daughter or playing with his grandchildren. During this period, he has developed a strong desire for chocolate pudding and potato chips and has gained 10 kg (22 lb). He appears unkempt. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Mental status examination shows apathy and a blunt affect. He avoids answering questions and instead comments on the individuals he saw in the waiting room. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 28/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease (AD) manifests with cognitive and behavioral changes. However, AD usually is associated with short-term memory loss and temporospatial disorientation, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, AD usually has an insidious progression, whereas this patient's symptoms have progressed over the course of 6 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease (PD) may cause personality changes, especially in advanced disease. However, patients with PD also present with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Advanced cases of Huntington disease manifest with apathy and other behavioral changes, as seen in this patient. However, this condition has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and typically also manifests with abnormal (choreiform) movements, which are absent in this patient. Huntington disease may manifest without a family history, but this is a very rare event, occurring only in 1–3% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Although Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease may manifest with signs and symptoms of dementia such as the behavioral and personality changes seen in this patient, however, the neurologic deterioration in this disease usually occurs more rapidly, taking place over the course of weeks-to-months and resulting in death within ∼ 1 year of symptom onset. Patients would also present with other neurological manifestations such as myoclonic jerks, gait instability, seizures, and/or hallucinations.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically manifests in patients 50–60 years old and may cause behavioral changes in late stages of the disease. However, ALS causes chronic, progressive, asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Advanced multiple sclerosis (MS) may cause cognitive changes in some patients. However, patients with MS have a history of relapsing/remitting weakness, numbness, and loss of balance, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, MS typically manifests with impaired vision, color blindness, Lhermitte sign, absent abdominal reflex, and/or signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign), which are also absent in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Although Wilson disease may cause behavioral changes, this condition usually manifests with liver disease and neurologic features such as dysarthria, parkinsonism, and drooling, which this patient does not have. Additionally, the disease typically manifests in patients < 35 years of age.

H) INCORRECT:

Although normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a potential cause of dementia, this condition typically manifests with gait disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and urinary incontinence (“wet, wacky, and wobbly”), which this patient lacks. Additionally, NPH usually manifests in older patients (> 60 years of age) or as a consequence of CNS infections and intracranial hemorrhages.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

I) CORRECT:

Personality changes, disinhibited behavior, and binge-eating (particularly sweet foods) in a middle-aged adult with intact memory are highly suspicious for frontotemporal dementia. This condition has a rapid progression compared to other dementias (see “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table), with patients surviving an average of approximately 6–9 years after symptom onset. In later stages, parkinsonism is also common. Diagnosis is made clinically, and can be supported via neuroimaging (MRI showing atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes) and FDG-PET/CT (showing frontotemporal hypoperfusion and hypometabolism).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a condition that is generally associated with pathological intracellular inclusion bodies, which are usually caused by mutations in tau proteins.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for the evaluation of progressive memory loss for the past 5 months. During the last 2 weeks, she has also had problems getting dressed and finding her way back home from the grocery store. She has had several episodes of jerky, repetitive, twitching movements that resolved spontaneously. She used to work as a teacher but quit her job due to her memory loss. The patient has hypertension. There is no family history of serious illness. Her only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. She is oriented only to person and place. She follows commands and speaks fluently, but sometimes cannot recall objects. She is unable to read and seems to have difficulty recognizing objects. Cranial nerves II-XII are intact. Examination shows full muscle strength. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative disease caused by cerebral accumulation of misfolded protein particles called prions. Normal prion proteins (PrPc) are found on the surface of cortical neurons and are protective against free radicals. Misfolded proteins (PrPSc) have more beta-sheets in their secondary structures, thereby changing their conformation. These misfolded proteins accumulate into plaques, causing neuronal cell death and spongiform encephalopathy. As there is no curative treatment for CJD, management is supportive and most patients die within 12 months of diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Extracellular senile plaques made of Aβ protein are associated with Alzheimer disease (AD), which manifests with insidious chronic memory loss, language deficits, and temporal and spatial disorientation. The memory loss seen in patients with AD is gradual and affects short-term memory first. This patient's rapid progression within 5 months and associated myoclonus are inconsistent with AD.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe cerebral ischemia (i.e., stroke) causes irreversible neurologic deficits, and multiple strokes can cause vascular dementia (VD). Patients with VD typically develop a stepwise decline in function (following each ischemic event), as well as focal deficits such as hemiparesis, unilateral visual field deficits, urinary incontinence, and behavioral changes. Although this patient does have risk factors for an ischemic event (e.g., older age, hypertension), the rapid, nonstepwise progression of her symptoms is not typical for VD. Her myoclonus and normal sensorimotor neurological exam would also be unlikely in the setting of vascular dementia.

D) INCORRECT:

Substantia nigra degeneration occurs in Parkinson disease (PD). The age of onset of PD is around 60 years, but dementia develops late in the course of the disease rather than within 5 months. In addition, the motor symptoms associated with PD are bradykinesia/akinesia, a resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability, and a Parkinsonian gait, not myoclonus. Although patients can have trouble projecting their voice or initiating speech, aphasia and agnosia are also not associated with PD.

E) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease is characterized by copper accumulation in the liver, cornea, and central nervous system; particularly within the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum. Neurologic symptoms include dysarthria, Parkinsonism, drooling, and behavioral changes, such as depression, irritability, and psychosis. Patients also develop liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis, hepatitis, acute liver failure) and Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit lamp examination. Though this patient has some speech difficulty and motor anomalies, she does not have manifestations of liver disease or Kayser-Fleischer rings and is older than the typical age of onset for Wilson disease (5–35 years of age).

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased CSF absorption in the arachnoid villi is the cause of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). The classic patient is represented by the mnemonic “wet, wacky, and wobbly,” which refers to the classic triad of symptoms: urinary incontinence, dementia, and abnormal gait. Symptoms develop gradually, and aphasia, agnosia, and myoclonus are not typically associated with NPH. Although motor strength is preserved in these patients, they often have hyperreflexia and a positive Babinski sign.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

G) INCORRECT:

An increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4 causes Huntington disease (HD), an autosomal dominant hereditary disease that typically manifests around 40 years of age. Patients develop dementia, depression, and/or anxiety, along with choreiform movements (more irregular motions than the repetitive, twitch-like motions of myoclonus seen in this patient). Although patients with HD can develop akinetic mutism, dysarthria, and dysphagia, aphasia and agnosia are uncommon. In addition, this patient is older than the typical onset of HD, and she has no family history of neurodegenerative disorders.
questions.hint: Rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus with associated aphasia and agnosia are suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

questions.text: Laboratory studies, including serum vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin), thyroxine (T4), and thyroid-stimulating hormone concentrations, are within normal limits. A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against ganglioside GM1 are diagnostic of Guillain-Barré syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by bilateral ascending flaccid paralysis that usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. It is not associated with dementia or myoclonus.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased α-synuclein protein concentration is seen in Lewy body dementia. Although CJD and Lewy body dementia have similar features, such as prominent visual disturbances and myoclonus, Lewy body dementia has a much slower progression, with fluctuations in cognition and level of alertness, whereas CJD is much more rapidly progressive.

C) CORRECT:

Although definitive diagnosis of CJD is only possible via postmortem histopathological and biochemical analysis, recent studies have shown that CJD is characterized by the presence of neuron-specific enolase, S100 protein, tau protein, and 14-3-3 protein on CSF analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of oligoclonal bands on CSF analysis is characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS) and results from the elevation of CSF immunoglobulin levels compared to other protein components. MS often manifests first with impaired vision and color blindness, progressing to upper motor neuron weakness and sensory loss as demyelination of the brain spreads. It is not associated with rapidly progressive dementia or myoclonus.

CSF studies are not required for the diagnosis of MS in patients with clinical and MRI findings consistent with the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) are found in a number of diseases, including diabetes, stiff person syndrome, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, Parkinson's disease, and cerebellar disorders. These antibodies are not seen in CJD.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased β-amyloid protein (Aβ protein) concentration in CSF is seen in Alzheimer's disease. Improper cleavage of the Aβ protein leads to extracellular aggregation, decreasing the circulating amount of protein. Although Alzheimer's disease is also a form of progressive dementia, the progression is often insidious and occurs over decades. Moreover, it is not associated with myoclonus or seizures.
questions.hint: This test has been shown to have a 92% sensitivity and 80% specificity for sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband for the evaluation of progressive memory loss, which he reports began approximately 2 weeks ago. During this time, she has had problems getting dressed and finding her way back home after running errands. She has also had several episodes of jerky, repetitive, twitching movements that resolved spontaneously. She is oriented only to person and place. She follows commands and speaks fluently. She is unable to read and has difficulty recognizing objects. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Extracellular senile plaques made of Aβ protein are associated with Alzheimer disease (AD), which manifests with progressive memory loss, language deficits, and temporal and spatial disorientation. The memory loss seen in patients with AD is gradual and affects short-term memory first. This patient's rapid progression within the past 2 weeks and associated myoclonus are inconsistent with AD.

B) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease is characterized by copper accumulation in the liver, cornea, and central nervous system; particularly within the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum. Neurologic symptoms include parkinsonism, drooling, and behavioral changes such as depression, irritability, and psychosis. Patients also present with liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis, hepatitis, acute liver failure), dysarthria, and almost always Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp examination. While this patient has some speech difficulties and motor anomalies, she does not have signs of liver disease or Kayser-Fleischer rings, and she is older than the typical age of onset for Wilson disease (5–35 years).

C) CORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by cerebral accumulation of misfolded protein particles called prions. Normal prion proteins (PrPc) are found on the surface of cortical neurons and are protective against free radicals. Misfolded prion proteins (PrPSc) have more beta-sheets in their secondary structures, which changes their conformation. These misfolded proteins accumulate into plaques, causing neuronal cell death and spongiform encephalopathy. As there is no curative treatment for CJD, management is supportive and most patients die within 12 months of diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe cerebral ischemia (i.e., stroke) causes irreversible neurologic deficits, and multiple strokes can cause vascular dementia (VD). Patients with VD typically present with a stepwise decline in function (following each ischemic event), as well as focal deficits such as hemiparesis, unilateral visual field deficits, urinary incontinence, and behavioral changes. This patient's rapid, nonstepwise progression of symptoms and myoclonus are not typical of VD.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased number of CAG repeats in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4 causes Huntington disease (HD), an autosomal dominant hereditary disorder that most commonly manifests around 40 years of age. Patients present with dementia, depression, and/or anxiety, along with choreiform movements (more irregular than the myoclonus motions seen in this patient). Dementia in HD usually first occurs in advanced stages of the disease. Also, this patient is older than the typical age of onset and has no family history of neurodegenerative disorders.

F) INCORRECT:

Substantia nigra degeneration occurs in Parkinson disease (PD). Dementia associated with PD is insidious and unlikely to progress rapidly within 2 weeks, as seen in this patient. In addition, the motor symptoms associated with PD are bradykinesia/akinesia, a resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability, and a Parkinsonian gait and not myoclonus, which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which causes myoclonus (jerky, repetitive, twitching movements) and rapidly-progressive dementia associated with aphasia and agnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening mental status over the past month. Her husband reports that she was initially experiencing lapses in memory but has recently started having difficulties performing activities of daily living. She appears withdrawn and avoids eye contact. Examination shows diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. A cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows elevated concentration of 14-3-3 protein. Four months later, the patient dies. Pathologic examination of the brain on autopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Degeneration of the substantia nigra pars compacta
Marked atrophy of caudate and putamen
Atrophy limited to the frontal and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the substantia nigra pars compacta and eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Lewy bodies) within neurons are typical histological features of Parkinson disease (PD). Although PD can manifest with signs of dementia, which is seen in this patient, the hallmark features of bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor are absent here. Furthermore, such rapid progression and death within months of symptom onset is not typical of PD. In addition, elevated levels of 14-3-3 protein in CSF would not be expected in PD.
Image Description:

Photomicrographs of a substantia nigra tissue sample (A: H&E stain, 500x magnification; B: immunochemical α-synuclein stain, 400x magnification)

Image A: An eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion (Lewy body; blue overlay) is visible inside a neuron. There is a large accumulation of neuromelanin (brown granules; green overlay).

Image B: A neurite staining positive for α-synuclein is visible in the center of the image (Lewy neurite; yellow overlay).

Lewy bodies and neurites are seen in various neurodegenerative disorders, e.g., Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Atrophy and gliosis in the caudate and putamen basal ganglia are typical histological features of Huntington disease (HD). Although HD can lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms like dementia in late stages of the disease, patients typically initially present with movement abnormalities, e.g., chorea, as well as hyperreflexia, which are absent in this patient. Furthermore, symptoms in HD usually first appear much earlier in life (around 40 years of age), and often progress over decades, as opposed to months, until death. In addition, elevated levels of 14-3-3 protein in CSF would not be expected in HD.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

This condition is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo. These findings in a patient with chorea are consistent with Huntington disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Multifocal areas of inflammation, demyelination, and gliosis are histological hallmarks of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS can present with memory deficits, but this is usually a very late feature. The disease more typically presents with impaired vision, color blindness, the Lhermitte sign, and signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign), none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, MS would not involve such a rapid progression within months of symptom onset. Lastly, elevated levels of 14-3-3 protein in CSF are not characteristic of MS.

D) INCORRECT:

Extracellular plaques composed of amyloid beta peptides and intracellular accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (neurofibrillary tangles) are typical histological features of Alzheimer disease (AD). Although AD initially manifests with short-term memory loss, which is seen in this patient, other classic findings are absent here, e.g., impaired naming and language comprehension or temporospatial disorientation. Most importantly, AD has an insidious onset and progresses slowly over several years, whereas this patient's symptoms progressed rapidly within 4 months. In addition, elevated levels of 14-3-3 protein in CSF are not characteristic of AD.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral tissue (Gallyas silver stain)

Intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (neurofibrillary tangles) are visible in multiple neurons (examples indicated by green overlay).

Neurofibrillary tangles are a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease but are also found in other conditions.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of intracytoplasmic vacuoles within neurons of the cerebral and cerebellar cortex (spongiform encephalopathy) is the characteristic histological feature of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) and other prion diseases. In addition to the classic features displayed by this patient, CJD can also lead to akinetic mutism, seizures, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., visual hallucinations, depression). Electroencephalogram of patients with CJD typically shows triphasic periodic sharp wave complexes. The disease has a rapid course that often leads to death within 12 months.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cortical brain tissue (H&E stain)

The tissue shows spongiform degeneration, which is the result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles of varying size (green overlay).

This is the characteristic histopathological appearance of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (detection of prions is only possible via immunohistochemistry).

F) INCORRECT:

Loss of neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes is the defining histological feature of frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Although FTD can manifest with early changes in personality and behavior (e.g., inappropriate social behavior), which are seen in this patient, memory is typically unaffected. Furthermore, the mean survival of patients with FTD is approximately 6–9 years after symptom onset, much longer than the 4 months seen in this case. In addition, elevated levels of 14-3-3 protein in CSF would not be expected in FTD.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.
questions.hint: Rapidly progressive mental deterioration (dementia, behavioral abnormalities, altered mood), startle myoclonus, and elevated 14-3-3 protein concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid are highly suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the office by his wife because of depressed mood and increased forgetfulness for the past 4 months. His wife notes that during this time, he has had difficulty remembering his daily schedule at work. Last week, he forgot to pick up their grandchildren from school. The patient acknowledges his situation and says, “I'm so tired of feeling like a burden to others. I want to end it all soon.” His father was diagnosed with dementia at the age of 62 years and died 1 year later. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 22/30. Examination discloses involuntary muscle twitching. On neurologic examination, deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Electroencephalography shows triphasic periodic sharp wave complexes. An MRI of the brain shows signal hyperintensity in the basal ganglia and temporal and frontal cortices. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chelation therapy is used in the treatment of Wilson disease, which is characterized by copper accumulation in the liver, cornea, and central nervous system (particularly within the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum). Affected individuals can develop dementia, behavioral changes (e.g., depression), and myoclonus, as seen here. However, this patient has no other findings suggestive of Wilson disease (e.g., dysarthria, Parkinsonism, drooling, tremor) and is older than the typical age of onset for Wilson disease (5–35 years of age). Chelation therapy is not useful in the treatment of CJD.

B) INCORRECT:

Monoamine-depleting therapy is indicated for the treatment of hyperkinetic movements in patients with Huntington disease (HD), an autosomal dominant hereditary disease that typically manifests around 40 years of age. Affected individuals can develop hyperreflexia and, rarely, myoclonus. However, choreiform movements (rapid, irregular motions) are more common than the involuntary twitching motions (myoclonus) seen in this patient. Although individuals with HD can develop dementia and depression, these features are more common in advanced stages. In addition, MRI of the brain in HD shows atrophy of the striatum, not signal hyperintensity in the basal ganglia and temporal and frontal cortices. Monoamine-depleting therapy is not useful in the treatment of CJD.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventriculoperitoneal shunting is used to treat normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This patient has signs of dementia, hyperreflexia, and a positive Babinski sign, all of which can be seen in NPH. However, he lacks other characteristic features of this condition (e.g., urinary incontinence, abnormal gait). Moreover, brain MRI in patients with NPH shows ventriculomegaly, not signal hyperintensity in the basal ganglia and temporal and frontal cortices. Ventriculoperitoneal shunting is not useful in the treatment of CJD.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

D) CORRECT:

This patient has CJD, which is caused by misfolded proteins (prions). Most cases of CJD are sporadic, but 10–15% are familial, and < 1% are acquired (e.g., via transmission during medical procedures, through ingestion of contaminated beef or human brain). This patient, who has a family history of a first-degree relative diagnosed with dementia at the age of 62 years and a rapidly fatal course, likely has the familial variant. Most patients with CJD die within 12 months after the onset of disease manifestations. No curative treatment is available; supportive care is the most appropriate intervention and should include communication with family, hospice evaluation, symptomatic treatment (e.g., benzodiazepines to treat myoclonus), and palliative care.
Image Description:

MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticholinesterase therapy (e.g., donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine) is used in the treatment of Alzheimer disease (AD), which manifests with dementia. Affected individuals can develop noncognitive symptoms, such as mood disorders and myoclonus, as seen here. However, in patients with AD, EEG shows slower basic rhythms, not triphasic periodic sharp wave complexes. In addition, MRI of the brain shows cerebral atrophy, not signal hyperintensity in the basal ganglia and temporal and frontal cortices. Anticholinesterase therapy is not useful in the treatment of CJD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with depression, subacute dementia, myoclonus, and hyperreflexia. These manifestations, along with his family history and MRI and EEG findings, are consistent with a diagnosis of familial Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the office for worsening mental status over the past 2 months. His wife reports that he was initially experiencing lapses in memory, and over the past 3 weeks, he has started having difficulty performing activities of daily living. Yesterday, he got lost going to the post office down the street. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert but verbally uncommunicative. Muscle strength is normal. Reflexes are 2+ in bilateral upper and lower extremities. He has diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. Mental status examination shows a blunt affect. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Alzheimer disease initially manifests with short-term memory loss and temporospatial disorientation, as seen in this patient, impaired naming and language comprehension, as well as mood and behavioral changes would also be prominent. Myoclonus does not occur in the early stages of Alzheimer disease. Most importantly, Alzheimer disease has an insidious onset and progresses slowly over several years, whereas this patient's symptoms progressed rapidly within 2 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) manifests with movement abnormalities and the defining symptom is chorea, which is absent in this patient. Furthermore, myoclonus is an atypical symptom of HD that occurs only rarely. Neuropsychiatric symptoms such as dementia and apathy can occur but appear at advanced stages, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressing mental decline combined with myoclonus and mutism, as seen in this patient, are typical clinical findings in patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The disease has a rapid course that often leads to death within 12 months.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease may present with cognitive impairment and myoclonus, but neurologic features, such as dysarthria, parkinsonism, and drooling, are much more common. Other typical findings of Wilson disease, such as liver damage and Kayser-Fleischer rings, are also absent. Finally, the disease typically manifests in patients < 35 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior (e.g., inappropriate social behavior) while memory and orientation initially remain intact, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
questions.hint: The electroencephalogram of this patient with rapidly progressing symptoms of dementia would show triphasic periodic sharp-wave complexes.
